comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
Seems to me that train is running north, towards Sydney.

I don't know when they changed the terminoligy,  but at one time,  the train from Sydney to Melbourne was the "Melbourne Express"   and the train from Melbourne to Sydney was the "Sydney Express"

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] Wikipedia states the same "...the name depended on the direction of travel..."

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content:
...The C38 class were first conceived in 1938. They suffered many delays during construction - mostly due to the Second World War. 3801 was the first engine completed and entered service in January 1943. The last in the class, 3830 entered service in November 1949. 

3809 was built at the New South Wales Government Railway Workshops at Cardiff in Newcastle.

By 1951 diesel locomotives started appearing on the rails of NSW. These gradually took the "glamour workings" away from the 38 class, who would be confined to all-stations passenger and even goods trains. They could still be found working The Newcastle Flyer up until December 1970.[..
